body: looks fine. update the README? (zipkin-anormdb/)

I think the bug/key insight is that we are inconsistent. Many parts of the
code treat span name case insensitively, but some don't. I'm not sure we
should be case sensitive, and I don't mind us enforcing lowercase on the
wire (just as http2 does). However, we should be consistent with the answer
of if we are case sensitive or not. If we are, that only works for certain
character sets, so might imply a constraint on the character set of span
name.
both solutions sounds file, from user point of view, it's nice to have them display with cases such as the service name (but you still query using lower case"
some test failures you might want to look at
I think this can be closed now as per https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-java/pull/30 ?
@adriancole fixed!

Yeah I suspect so. Folks are generally moving towards Kafka, though some
use other systems like kenesis.

We have an issue about Kafka so maybe high time we call this a few real
decision ;)
gracias
ps the java project is now in sync with the schema used by anorm
closed via #682
Closing since PR is merged.

I'm not sure case insensitivity is a good idea with regards to being able to offer different storage backends, which might _or might not_ offer the ability to query the span name that way, and I don't think  schema-on-write is a thing that should be done for user-provided strings like this.

My 2p is either we do lowercase on store (which implies searches also
lowercase on the way in), or we leave it case sensitive (and be consistent
about it :P)
I love that you fixed this. Since this is quite subtle.. can you put an example query in ZipkinQueryServerFeatureTest, to ensure the encoding rules are known?
I'm gonna merge as we need to do a release. if you don't mind, add a test to ZipkinQueryServerFeatureTest if you don't forget :) The other coverage is great.
<3 @srijs

I hate to say it, but I think we are nearly a point where recreating a UI would be less work than maintaining it.

Good news: It is possible to update all libraries with the exception of dagre-d3.

Bad news: there's custom trimming involved, and this isn't represented in the bower file. This means I can't update it easily unless we want to check in a lot of junk.

Ugly news:  dagre-d3 is very tangled. If you try to update it, you'll get in a mess between versions of dagre and d3. After a few hours, I was unable to sort problems such as undefined references to functions with requirejs shims. See #772, which says all that work is wasted as we need another means to create sankey or similar diagram.

Next step:

If we don't want to throw away the UI, we need to maintain it far better than we are now. We probably want to stop checking in assets into src/main/resources and using something like [bower-installer](https://github.com/craigburke/bower-installer-gradle) to install them at build time like other deps.

cc @abesto @eirslett


Yup, it would be nice to use something else than dagre!
One option we could do in the meantime is to bundle dagre-d3 with its version of d3 in a self-contained, isolated module. Then, the rest of the UI could be developed independently, and draw the graph by using the graph's public API. jQuery and D3 would be hidden inside the private scope and not pollute the global namespace.

One more thing we have just realized.
When we run it locally with 3 test apps, we create 16 annotations. When executing this against RDS, we create 8 annotations.
Checking the differences, we have seen that the "sr", "ss" and related binary annotations were all in RDS. And the "cs" "cr" annotations and related binary annotations were none of them in RDS.

Nit:

Lets avoid forcing navigation to see what test input thats only used once is. I know many tests in zipkin are like that, but it is bad practice as it adds unnecessary and distracting indirection. In some cases, for example, I've found misnamed variables hiding bugs. Inlining eliminates that problem space.

To add more to my Nit (digging a deeper hole):

I should say inlining or locally declaring input where only used once. Ex. A misnamed variable is obvious when it is declared and used within the same few lines. Your variable is fine, just people do refactors and break things. Locals or inlining is great as say a future PR breaks this, you can usually see in the diff its context, whereas if the input is declared at the top of the file, you cant.

@eirslett well, I'm just thinking that these flags lift expectations of where assets are stored etc into public api. If we re-organize into pulling bower deps as opposed to storing them in the source tree, we'd break below's contract (maybe for the best).

```
  val webCacheResources = flag("zipkin.web.cacheResources", false, "cache static resources and mustache templates")
  val webResourcesRoot = flag("zipkin.web.resourcesRoot", "zipkin-web/src/main/resources", "on-disk location of resources")
```
Off with their heads!
We're still on jdk7 but that doesn't need to stop us.  What would be some alternatives for those that are stuck for the time being?

Ship libraries? Ex. if there's no custom code, then there's no reason to javac. Maybe upstream or find some internal build pipeline that permits use of javac 8. Often there's at least an experimental build for a JDK as old as 8 is.

For example, I think you guys needed kafka, and the upstream collector now supports it. Is there anything else needed to flip over? once there's nothing left, then there's no code you'd need to run javac 8 against.

unless.. you are saying your servers actually can't run jre 8, either, which makes the solution unfortunately simpler, which is use a version before the flip and lean elbows on whatever's blocking the ability to coexist with JRE 8.
+1 to move to 8

well both of your points are valid. It was a guess that nextSpanId was
escalated to a real type member (as opposed to any given annotation) for
the purpose of sequencing. I might be wrong. the async stuff, however, is
much more clearly about sequence. @Xylus can you verify?

what I am not clear on is why sequencing is important. It was brought up in the context of async spans in the document, where sequencing of async siblings (or, more precisely, of their 'beginSpan' events) doesn't strike me as particularly useful. On the other hand, in the sync context, the call/return pairs can be easily serialized by the timestamps because there is no clock skew in the parent span.

The use case that leads to this is frame-granularity tracing, like every
method call or cherry-picked ones. Without explicit ordering, you may not
be able to reconstruct the call graph exactly how it existed using only
time, particularly as timestamps are really millis *1000 in a lot of
instrumentation. Feel free to challenge this assumption.

Fair enough. `span.beginChildSpan()` can internally assign a sequence number, which can be emitted as a predefine span attribute. 

Adrian, could you please create a "Zipkin v.2 Data Model" doc in the Breakouts folder? There are too many open questions here to discuss in a linear chat.
@yurishkuro good point. Moved to https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ixxEs9TvhiGjJObGbRSPhSna3zHdadoUTQIZ5JKgLzU/edit

@adriancole @yurishkuro 
`nextSpanId`, and `async*` variables do similar stuff but are used in different circumstances in Pinpoint.

**nextSpanId**
We use both `nextSpanId` of the parent, and `parentSpanId` of the child to reconstruct the call graph. Do note that this was done to support in-process traces (is this frame-granularity trace?). For example:

```
* Note that "Span" in our case denotes a single node, "SpanEvent" denotes a method-level trace
----> | Span (id=1)
      | SpanEvent seq=0 (nextSpanId=11) -----> | Span (id=11, parentSpanId=1)
      | SpanEvent seq=1
      | SpanEvent seq=2 (nextSpanId=12) ----------> | Span (id=12, parentSpanId=1)
* Also Note that only RPC SpanEvents have nextSpanIds.
```

Without `nextSpanId`, we couldn't map Spans 11 and 12 to a SpanEvent and by extension give them ordering (as SpanEvents have sequences within them). `nextSpanId` is issued by the parent and the child uses it as it's Span id.
Plus, using both `nextSpanId` and `parentSpanId` to reconstruct the call graph helps in mitigating SpanId collision (two-way comparison.instead of one).

**async\* variables**
Similar to `nextSpanId` above, but used for context propagation across threads. We emulate an asynchronous call as a new Span internally (except we don't create a new node for it), kinda similar to the example above but with asynchronous invocations instead of RPC calls. For example,

```
----> Span (id=1)
      | SpanEvent seq=0
      | SpanEvent seq=1 (nextAsyncId=11) ----async----> | Async "Span" (id=11)
      | SpanEvent seq=2
```

This is exactly the same as what happens in RPC calls, except that a SpanEvent may have more than 1 asynchronous invocations :

```
----> Span (id=1)
      | SpanEvent seq=0
      | SpanEvent seq=1 (nextAsyncId=11) ----async----> | Async "Span" asyncSequence=0 (id=11)
      |                                  |---async----> | Async "Span" asyncSequence=1 (id=11)
      | SpanEvent seq=2
```

Hope I got everything right without confusing everyone too much.

PS. wanted to post something on this to the Google Docs, but didn't know how to edit it nicely :)

The `zipkin-web` terminates all traffic from the UI. One way to reduce surface area is to only expose `zipkin-web`. There's work to do in order to lock that down, and bear in mind I've not seen all things possible in finagle-land.

`zipkin-web` is a [TwitterServer](https://github.com/twitter/twitter-server), and very similar to [Finatra](https://github.com/twitter/finatra). Most patterns of Finatra could be applied to `zipkin-web`. To do authentication, you'd likely end up writing a filter or explicit code. I've found two examples:  [finatra-angular-example](https://github.com/pvoznenko/finatra-angular-example/blob/master/src/main/scala/com/acme/ShoppingCart/controllers/Api/UsersApi.scala#L19) and [finatra-tweet-example](https://github.com/twitter/finatra/blob/master/http/src/test/scala/com/twitter/finatra/http/integration/tweetexample/main/filters/AuthFilter.scala)

The subject of authorization would be slightly more complex. There's a mix of responsibilities inside `zipkin-web`, presumably folks optimizing for how much data is going to the browser, but honestly, I've no idea. This mix presents itself as some javascript components calling json endpoints, and mustache template rendering doing other things. This scatters the authorization concern a bit, as if there was only a "normal" json query api, you could just secure that. For example, to authorize by service, code would likely need to wrap the underlying SpanStore object as that's the choke-point for data.

The work involved in unwinding this problem is essentially refactoring the javascript UI to only use the query server's api. Authorization code could be much simpler, even at the http abstraction. That said, there would be a caveat, which is that you need to inspect the json to ensure a call to getTraces (by id) doesn't accidentally return data the user shouldn't see. That's because it isn't likely all storage implementations will be able to support transparent authorization.

Regardless, once the UI only makes calls to a narrowly defined set of endpoints, you'd have relatively straight-forward authorization. This would be whatever you can code in finatra, or any number of established patterns supported by [Spring Boot](http://projects.spring.io/spring-boot/), such as [OAuth](https://spring.io/blog/2015/02/03/sso-with-oauth2-angular-js-and-spring-security-part-v) (as [zipkin-java](https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin) is a boot app)

All I can add to that is that, while securing the Java query server (and also collector now) will be very straightforward, you would probably have to write your own UI in order to deal with the user experience of being denied access (assuming authentication could be done as a separate service, which is fairly easy if you have one already doing oauth etc.).
cc @adrianco I'll ping back when this is in a release
This is the scala implementation of https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-java/pull/35

Finatra being based on Finagle, I imagine it would be possible to make some sort of a Filter to perform authentication and resource protection scheme but UI work would be needed and probably some way to model the security model.

docker release is out. if you clone https://github.com/openzipkin/docker-zipkin, you can do the same spigo instructions as above after running `docker-compose up`. Only change is that you need to use your docker-machine's IP as opposed to localhost to POST the spans.

Refreshing it once again gives me 34 connection
Once again and I get 89 connections.

They are all executing the command "sleep" and they do not finish.
Sounds odd but fixable. The connection pool should be a Singleton.
Strange enough, it kind of hovered over 100 and stayed stable.  Still not conformtable having 100 unused connections

process, until we switch instrumentation to HTTP only. I forget the count
of each pool. Will have a look

wrote:

> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub

I see most of the connections are just sleeping doing nothing and they stay there forever.

So the DB Pool is set to max 32 connections, so if you have a single query and a single collector, that should be 64 (potentially stale) connections https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-anormdb/src/main/scala/com/twitter/zipkin/storage/anormdb/DB.scala#L46

There are ways to tune this to prune out connections, but fastest way to control connection count is to obviate the collector. Then at least you only tune one place and connections are reused across query and store.
cc @jcarres-mdsol
maybe related to #783

ACK this is a problem. we can't tell which the service is the parent without looking at the annotations. annotations within a span have mixed endpoints, so it is ambiguous.

For example, a binary annotation of server address, or a normal annotation of server receive or server send would indicate who the server is. similarly with client.

Hi, there.

We've added substantial documentation updates, far more than existed
before. Don't read too much into what's logged in old issues, but I will
have a look at it.

We now have verbose README files, detailing the minimum variables you need
to set, and doc folders on both zipkin and also the docker-zipkin projects.
Users no longer have to build the project as we took great effort to
publish binaries and also docker images.

The binaries are on bintray and docker images are on both quay and also
dockerhub.

Maybe if you can mention your specific use-case, we can update zipkin.io to
be more obvious.

I know there's still work to do, but you are far better off as you don't
have to run sbt or gradle ;) Regardless, we are on gitter.im on
openzipkin/zipkin and folks deploy in many ways. Many use docker, which we
support best. Some use chef or other tools.

Hope this helps and thanks for keeping us honest!

The schema functions better as an example to follow at the moment.  For individual cassandra clusters there are enough differences (i.e. datacenter, keyspace, users, etc) that make a generalized setup not a good idea.  In the future we could consider creating database migrations at which point we could think about using config variables.  Not sure when the road map for that would be, but would welcome any assistance :smile:  Another alternative could be a better readme outlining what variables could be changed and what some example fields might be.

Ah... I hadn't checked zipkin.io... I followed the link from README.md to http://twitter.github.com/zipkin instead. Can we just change that?

I should clarify that I'm not using docker, so it looks like I should just grab a jar from bintray for each of the individual services I plan to use?

I know there has been a lot of work to separate out non-essential components but I hadn't thought to look in the subdirectories for readmes. It would be great if we could integrate that information into the zipkin.io docs as well.

It's called in the constructor of `org.twitter.zipkin.storage.cassandra.Repository` and as far as I can see there is currently no way of disabling it. I need control over what's being executed :) Ideally make zipkin not execute anything during startup and let me handle the database schema by myself.
